questions.text: Choose the correct set of statements regarding the course of the facial nerve 1) The extracranial part of facial nerve lies lateral to retromandibular vein 2) Facial nerve exits the skull via stylomastoid foramen 3) Greater petrosal nerve is a branch of facial nerve after the formation of geniculate ganglion 4) The facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve
questions.explanation:
Entry into Parotid Gland
  • Main trunk enters on the posteromedial surface of the parotid gland.

Division of Nerve
  • Divides within the gland, behind and superficial to the retromandibular vein (Statement 1) and external carotid artery (ECA).

Temporofacial vs. Cervicofacial Trunks
  • Temporofacial trunk: Contains more axons but fewer fascicles.
  • Cervicofacial trunk: Contains more fascicles but fewer axons.

Formation of Parotid Plexus
  • The trunks branch further to form the parotid plexus (pes anserinus) from which the terminal branches arise.

Terminal Branches
  • Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was diagnosed with Acoustic neuroma. Which among the following cranial nerve is the earliest to be involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features
  • Age 40-60, both sexes equally affected
  • Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus
  • Imbalance, facial numbness, dysphagia in later stages

Cranial Nerves Involved
  • V: Earliest to be involved (Option A), Reduced corneal sensitivity, facial numbness
  • VII: Hypoaesthesia, delayed blink reflex, reduced lacrimation
  • X, XI: Dysphagia, hoarseness
  • May involve other cranial nerves as disease progress

Investigations
  • Pure tone audiometry: High-frequency sensorineural loss, roll-over or decay phenomenon seen. (Roll over associated with vestibular symptoms is called as Tulio phenomenon)
  • Speech audiometry: Poor discrimination
  • MRI with gadolinium: Gold standard, ice-cream cone appearance seen.

Vestibular schwannoma - Wikipedia" data-tags="" height="643" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/VAFezU3EBcfDqXek1Ba51738729188.png" width="500" />

Treatment
  • Surgery: Middle cranial fossa, translabyrinthine, suboccipital, combined approach
  • Radiosurgery: Gamma knife, Cyberknife

Differential Diagnosis
  • Meningioma, epidermoid, arachnoid cyst, metastases

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. Which of the following mechanisms is associated with the pathogenesis of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Dilatation of the internal auditory artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent vertigo, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in his left ear, along with progressive hearing loss. He is diagnosed with Meniere’s disease, and audiometric testing is performed. Which part of the cochlea and what frequency range is typically affected first?

options.label: A
options.text: Apical turn of the cochlea is affected causing high-frequency hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Basal turn of the cochlea is affected causing low-frequency hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Apical turn of the cochlea is affected causing low-frequency hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: Basal turn of the cochlea is affected causing high-frequency hearing loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Apical turn of the cochlea is affected causing low-frequency hearing loss

questions.text: The inner ear, or the labyrinth has a central chamber called the vestibule with a spherical and elliptical recess, each accommodating important structures of the membranous labyrinth. What structure does the elliptical recess accommodate?
While assessing a patient’s vestibular function, an ENT surgeon repeatedly presses and releases the tragus of the patient, eliciting a positive response. What would this finding indicate?
questions.explanation:
Purpose

To Assess the integrity of the bony labyrinth and detect perilymph fistulas (abnormal openings in the bony labyrinth)
 

Principle

Pressure changes in the external ear canal can be transmitted to the inner ear through a fistula, triggering vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), resulting in nystagmus and possibly vertigo
 

Procedure
  • Pressure Application: Intermittent pressure applied on the tragus or using a Siegel's speculum.
  • Observation: Eyes are observed for nystagmus and the patient is queried about vertigo.
 

Interpretation
  • Positive Fistula Test:
    • Indicates a perilymph fistula
    • Nystagmus direction helps locate the fistula
    • Indicates a functional labyrinth
  • Negative Fistula Test:
    • Usually indicates intact bony labyrinth
    • False negatives can occur if covered by cholesteatoma
 

Positive test causes
  • Erosion of horizontal semicircular canals as in cholesteatoma
  • Surgically created window in horizontal canal
  • Superior canal dehiscence
  • Abnormal opening in the oval or round window

Negative test
  • No fistula

False-negative causes

  • Surgically confirmed cases of labyrinthine fistula
  • Cholesteatoma covers the site of fistula
  • Dead labyrinth
 

False-Positive (Hennebert's Sign)

Hennebert's Sign: Positive test without a fistula; can occur in:

  • Congenital Syphilis: Hypermobile stapes footplate.
  • Ménière's Disease: Due to a distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about vestibular evoked myogenic potentials?

options.label: A
options.text: The cervical VEMP is picked up in the sternocleidomastoid

options.label: B
options.text: The vestibulospinal arc mediates through the lower brainstem

options.label: C
options.text: The ocular muscle that show potentials are the inferior oblique and inferior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used in diagnosing the origin of a neuroma

questions.correct_answer: C. The ocular muscle that show potentials are the inferior oblique and inferior rectus
questions.explanation:
cVEMP (Cervical VEMP)

oVEMP (Ocular VEMP)

Target muscle

Sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle in the neck

Ocular muscles (inferior oblique or superior rectus)
 

Nerve pathway

Saccule → Inferior vestibular nerve → Vestibular nuclei → Ipsilateral vestibulospinal tract → Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) → SCM

Utricle → Superior vestibular nerve → Vestibular nuclei → Medial longitudinal fasciculus → Oculomotor nerve (CN III) → Inferior oblique and superior rectus muscles
 

Stimulation

  • Primarily, air-conducted sounds stimulate the saccule
  • Bone-conducted sounds, stimulating both saccule and utricle
 

Clinical uses

  • Assessing saccular function
  • Investigating acoustic neuroma (inferior vestibular nerve)
  • Diagnosing Ménière's disease
  • Assessing utricular function
  • Investigating acoustic neuroma (superior vestibular nerve)
  • Diagnosing superior canal dehiscence
 

Differences

  • Sensitive to air-conducted sounds
  • Vestibulospinal arc is mediated through the lower brain stem
  • Responds to both air and bone conduction
  • Vestibulo-ocular reflex is mediated through the upper brainstem

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of severe vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the left ear. An Audiogram is taken and is shown below. Which of the following structures is primarily involved in the pathophysiology of the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Role in Ménière's Disease

Endolymphatic sac

Dysfunction causes defective absorption of endolymph, leading to endolymphatic hydrops, which results in vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and aural fullness.

Cochlear duct (scala media)

Distension of the cochlear duct affects hearing, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. It is the primary site affected in the auditory portion of the inner ear.

Saccule

Distended saccule may press against the stapes footplate, potentially contributing to vestibular symptoms and vertigo in the advanced stages of the disease. (Option C)

Semicircular canals

Secondary involvement causes vestibular symptoms such as vertigo, but they are not the primary site of the pathology in Ménière’s disease. (Option A)

Reissner membrane

In severe cases, the bulging of this membrane can result in herniation into the scala vestibuli, worsening the symptoms of vertigo and hearing loss. (Option D)

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with worsening right ear hearing loss and tinnitus resembling a heartbeat for 6 months. Examination reveals a pulsatile neck mass and a red, bulging tympanic membrane. Biopsy and MRI findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Glomus tumor (Paraganglioma)

Definition

Tumors originating from the paraganglia are known as paragangliomas, with glomus tumors being a specific type of paraganglioma.

Tumour type

Benign (most common benign tumor of middle ear)

Origin

Paraganglionic cells or glomus bodies .

Prevalence

Commonly seen in middle-aged individuals (40-50 years), with a higher prevalence in females

Types

  1. Glomus tympanicum: Arise from the promontory of the middle ear (tympanic plexus).
  2. Glomus jugulare: Arises from the dome of the jugular bulb (sympathetic plexus covering the jugular vein).

 

Spread

  • Inferiorly: To the jugular foramen
  • Anteriorly: Invading into the nasopharynx (blockage of eustachian tube)
  • Posteriorly: Invading the mastoid
  • Superiorly: To the posterior and middle cranial fossa (IX-XII cranial nerve palsy)
  • Laterally: To the tympanic membrane (present as a bleeding polyp of the external auditory canal).
  • Medially: Invading the labyrinth and petrous pyramid (dizziness and facial palsy).

 Fig: Spread of Glomus Tumour

Fig: Spread of Glomus Tumour

 

Clinical manifestations
  • Hearing loss (gradually progressive conductive hearing loss)
  • Pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat like sounds): It is synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Bleeding from ear (profuse bleeding in case of polyp)
  • Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear.
  • Symptoms like headache, sweating, palpitation, hypertension, anxiety due to sympathetic excess (catecholamine release)

Histopathology

  • No capsule (locally invasive)
  • HPE reveals Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

               Fig: Zell Ballen Appearance of Glomus Tumour

Otoscopy

  • Red reflex through intact tympanic membrane and bulging tympanic membrane (glomus tympanicum).
  • “Rising sun" appearance due to the tumor originating from the floor of middle ear (glomus jugulare).

 

Diagnosis

  • CECT (IOC) shows erosion of the carotico-jugular spine on the diseased side, known as Phelp’s sign.

CT shows enlargement of the left jugular foramen with bone erosion (arrow)

 
  • MRI scan revealed microhemorrhages within the tumor which appear as white and gray dots on MRI, creating a "salt and pepper" appearance.
 

MRI shows a well-defined mass (arrow) in the left jugular foramen. The mass shows a "salt and pepper appearance,

 
  • Angiography is used to identify the arteries supplying the tumor.
